Alexa Hankins
Alexa Hankins
   • 1st
Verified • 1st
-- International Relations Major at Boston University | Concentrating in Environment and Development
-- International Relations Major at Boston University | Concentrating in Environment and Development
2mo • 
 
2 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
As this summer comes to a close, I'd like to reflect on my internship with Biodiversity for a Livable Climate, where I was given the freedom to pursue projects of interest as a member of the community outreach team. 

I was able to contribute to the Featured Creatures blog twice, where I wrote about the North Atlantic Right Whale and the Burmese Python. These species have intense histories surrounding conservation, and allowed me to construct narratives centered on the relationship between public policy and healthy, biodiverse ecosystems.

Additionally, I was given the opportunity to present my knowledge of AI’s environmental impact with the wonderful scientists, activists, and professionals of the Eco Restoration Alliance. This experience allowed me to polish my presentation and communication skills, and I’d like to thank Jon Schull for facilitating my involvement!

There are many projects that I couldn’t fit in this post, so it’s safe to say that this was an incredible and comprehensive experience- I received no shortage of valuable perspectives and vital skills I’ll be able to carry through the next stages of my professional and academic journey. I would especially like to thank Louise Mitchell for her attentive mentorship and for making this role possible!

Biodiversity for a Livable Climate
Biodiversity for a Livable Climate
2,487 followers
2,487 followers
4mo • 
 
4 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
Much of the U.S. is sweating through record-breaking temperatures this week. We'll hear a lot about cooling centers and public fans, but it’s time to talk about the planet’s most undervalued cooling system: water. 

Forests, soils, and oceans manage heat naturally, if we let them.

Led by Hart Hagan and featuring guest instructors Brock Dolman (OCCIDENTAL ARTS & ECOLOGY CENTER), Anastassia Makarieva, Dr. Katie Ross, Walter Jehne (Regenerate Earth), and Didi Pershouse, this new course from Bio4Climate reveals what the climate conversation is missing and how water, not just carbon, holds the key to cooling a warming planet.

Register by July 10!
https://lnkd.in/dKvpQN25
